lesson.page: Parachutes are used to slow the fall of objects. They work because the air exerts a force on them as they move. This force is called drag and counteracts the downward pull of gravity.
The faster you go, the bigger the drag on the parachute. At low speeds the drag is small and a parachutist will accelerate downwards due to gravity.
As he accelerates, the drag increases, until it equals the pull of gravity. Then he falls at a constant velocity, called the terminal velocity.

The force on the parachute depends on many things, including the area of the parachute and the square of the speed. The square of the terminal velocity is, therefore, inversely proportional to the area - to halve the terminal velocity, we have to increase the area four times..
Parachutes are not just about size. They also need a hole in the top to allow some air to pass through smoothly - otherwise it builds up and makes the parachute rock from side to side.
In this game, you have to design a parachute that will safely land a man in the target zone.
If the parachutist hits the ground faster than 6m/s, he will be injured. Be careful! His speed will depend on the wind speed as well as his terminal velocity.
If the terminal velocity is too slow, the parachutist will be blown away into the trees
Remember the hole at the top! If the parachute's hole is too small, your parachute will rock from side to side and could hurt your parachutist. If it is too large, then the parachute won't work!
Use the sliders to control the size of the parachute, before launching your plane. You can have as many goes as you like!
